awd_titl_txt: Recruitment and Retention of Women in Engineering and Engineering Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Because men make up more than two-thirds of the manufacturing workforce in the United States, women are an untapped resource of talent to help US manufacturers become more globally competitive. Working collaboratively with industry partners to address the regional demand for gender-diversity in engineering and engineering technology (E&ET) occupations, this project at Norwalk Community College in Connecticut aims to to attract more females to the college E&ET education programs. Building on research findings, the project will focus on the following student-centered objectives: (1) designing and implementing strategies for recruiting and retaining female students in E&ET programs; (2) retaining female students by implementing high-impact practices within courses and through student support programs; and (3) designing and delivering a contextualized Intermediate algebra course that includes research based methods for increasing success rates of female students. Because the college has recently been designated a Hispanic Serving Institution, the project will strive to increase in the number of Hispanic female students, further supporting the diversification of the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics workforce. A comprehensive evaluation will be completed to help determine which strategies work best and for whom. This project may provide a model that other community colleges and employers can use to increase workforce diversity.

The new recruitment and retention strategies will build upon earlier ATE projects that have been conducted at peer institutions and use resources that have been developed to address the gender gap in E&ET programs. Panel discussions with local business and industry partners will aim to raise awareness of the program on campus and encourage faculty to enhance their course curricula. Using online training and campus workshops, faculty will learn about tools and techniques for supporting diverse learners and how to apply these techniques to their courses. The project will design and pilot a contextualized Intermediate Algebra course, because most of the college E&ET students start at that level, and it is a required course for undecided students. Female students enrolled in that course will be encouraged to pursue a degree in E&ET. The course will include female friendly examples, group work in class, and team projects where women can develop a sense of community and ownership over their learning.  This course will be a model for other faculty members who aim to incorporate context- and female-supportive practices in their curriculum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Goals:

This project, funded by an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) grant, aimed to address the critical need for a more gender-diverse workforce in engineering and technology fields by implementing evidence-based recruitment and retention practices to increase number of women in these majors.  The project established several initiatives and activities including conducting outreach activities to promote engineering and engineering technology to women, organizing professional development workshops for college and local high school faculty and staff to raise awareness about gender equity in STEM, and developing a contextualized Intermediate Algebra course as a pilot model to attract female students to STEM fields.   

Broader impact:

A total of 27 high school counselors and STEM faculty attended professional development workshops that aimed to raise awareness about gender diversity challenges in STEM and provide actionable strategies to address these challenges. The workshops were well-received by participants, who highlighted the value of the interactive activities, exposure to real-world STEM applications, and discussions on addressing biases and barriers for women in STEM.

To raise awareness among college faculty and staff, the project sponsored two convocation speaker events and several professional development events. Over 200 college professionals attended the convocation keynotes featuring expert speakers who addressed diversity challenges in STEM education. The professional development workshops, on the other hand, provided more focused and practical strategies for faculty and staff. These events provided valuable professional development opportunities for educators, equipping them with the tools to create more welcoming, inclusive, and supportive learning environments for all students, particularly women in STEM fields. Over the course of the project, 94 college professionals attended these workshops.

To provide role models for women in engineering and engineering technology majors, the project hosted ten Women in STEM Speaker Series events. The speakers in this series came from various backgrounds, including quality engineering management, project coordination, and research architecture, including two program alumni who went on to successful careers in the field. This ongoing series provided a platform for female professionals in STEM fields to share their experiences and insights with students. The impact of this series was significant, with survey results showing positive shifts in student attitudes toward engineering, particularly among female students. The series was well-received by students, with comments highlighting the value of seeing real-world applications of engineering and gaining insights into different career paths. The students especially appreciated talks focusing on tasks taken by the professional in their everyday job and discussion of how what they learned in classrooms is being implemented at work. More than 200 students attended these talks.

Intellectual merit:

The project created a set of seven modules for the Intermediate Algebra course to encourage students to pursue STEM, especially engineering and technology majors. The modules have been published on the ATE Central website and are available for public access. These modules integrated real-world STEM applications into the traditional Intermediate Algebra curriculum. The course exposed students to the practical uses of mathematics in fields like physics, engineering, environmental science, and healthcare while bolstering the altruistic aspects of these topics. This intervention, piloted from Fall 2021 through Spring 2023, engaged over 300 students in contextualized sections and explored gender-specific outcomes, course performance, and changes in STEM identity through surveys and segmented regression analysis. The course's impact on attracting female students showed positive trends and revealed nuanced differences in how male and female students responded to the contextualized learning modules. More specifically, the data suggested that the impact of the modules on students' performance was significant for high-performing students. The findings offer valuable insights for educators aiming to broaden STEM participation and will be presented at the ASEE annual conference in 2025.

The overall impact in enrollment of women:

Overall, throughout its lifetime, the project had both achievements and setbacks regarding enrollment and retention trends in advancing gender diversity and student success in the engineering program. The project faced several challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic and the Connecticut Community College merger, that have possibly contributed to negative trends in women’s retention in the program. The merger redefined the definition of Norwalk Community College students, complicating year-to-year comparisons and making it more difficult to track progress accurately, which could negatively have affected the results in the final year.

Nevertheless, despite these challenges, the project had major achievements. The retention rates for women saw a significant improvement during the first year of the project, rising from 40% in Fall 2018 to a high of 90% in Fall 2019 before the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted the trend. Enrollment data shows a notable improvement compared to pre-project levels. In Fall 2018, women made up 12.5% of enrolled students, just before the project began. Since then, the percentage of women enrolled has consistently remained above these pre-project levels, peaking at 17.2% in Fall 2022 and settling at 14.9% in Fall 2023.


Last Modified: 12/17/2024
Modified by: Mobin Rastgar Agah
